title: Beautiful but people poop right outside
review: This is a beautiful, peaceful, uncrowded site on the Yamuna River. It's definitely worth a visit. Just don't be surprised if you step in human poop just outside the gates (that's where the tuk tuk drivers go while they are waiting for you. NO JOKE). The train stations in Delhi and Agra are the same: There is a ton of excrement on the tracks. We actually watched two women holding toddlers over the tracks while they pooped. One child missed and the mother just left it on the walkway where families sleep.

title: Not so spectacular maybe when it's overcast
review: Wanted to go back a couple of hours later when the sun came out not even inside just inside the front gate to take a phot and had our tickets but were refused.

title: Baby Taj!
review: Conveniently located as you drive into the city of Agra. Doesn't have the mad crowds that the other attraction. Lovely inlaid mosaic work. Nice place to amble around if the weather's good

title: Baby Taj
review: The first total marble mausoleum of mughal eraThe grounds were a delight to walk around. The lattice-work in the stone is also especially nice. Give yourself at least an hour to enjoy this gem.

title: Include the Baby Taj in your Agra Sites
review: The Baby Taj is well worth the visit, it's less crowded than the Taj Mahal and that helps to make it an enjoyable experience.

title: Good
review: it was good to see  but not like Taj Mahal . It is just good not excellent property but  this is awsome that in Agra is only city in world which have 3  world famous monuments .

title: Beautiful baby Taj
review: This monument is very peaceful and not crowded in the least. Its a must see when in Agra. A pre-cursor to the Taj for sure. We enjoyed and and loved the symmetry and mogul garden.

title: beautiful - don't miss it
review: affectionately called the "baby taj" because of it's resemblance to the taj mahal, the tomb of itimad-ud-daulah was actually build a few years before construction began on the the taj mahal.  this may sound crazy, but i actually found this more stunning than the taj mahal.  it is beautiful - if you're in agra, don't miss it.

title: Baby Taj
review: This attraction is referred to as the Baby Taj.  It influenced the design or the Taj Mahal.  I thought it was quite beautiful and well worth visiting.

title: Classic red stone architecture
review: Very quiet and peaceful place to start your excursion to Agra. With it's magnificent gardens helps you to relax from the disturbing town sounds.

title: Agra is not only Taj Mahal
review: This tomb is small and breathtakingly beautiful. Is distant from the Taj Mahal, but has the advantage of being a quiet and relaxed inside, without the massiveness of the Taj.

title: Worthwhile if you have the time
review: Not first priority but definetly a great monument with so much detail and less crowds.  Often called the baby taj.

title: a little gem
review: Visited the baby taj after the taj was not dissapointed. As others have said peaceful and serene a lovely respite form the bustle of Agra with amazing architecture and surrounds thrown in

title: Not worthy
review: We went to this place called 'Baby Taj' while touring Agra in May. This building has nothing special. Its just a room with a few graves. There is no guide available. There is no proper arrangement for drinking water.There are just few caretakers who are very rude and give an impression as if they own the building. We found no sense in visiting this place.

title: Serenity
review: This 'baby Taj' is a really tranquil spot. We had fun watching the squirrels in the garden. The inlay work is almost as good as the Taj and the lack of crowds certainly made this visit a pleasant experience.

title: mini-Taj Mahal
review: A lovely site to wander around.  Very peaceful & serene, less sterile than the Taj.  Enjoyed seeing friendly little squirrel creatures.

title: The forgotten Gem of Agra
review: This tomb, also known as the Baby Taj, is not the architectural wonder of the Taj Mahal.  However, the intricacies of the marble inlays goes far beyond the Taj Mahal.

title: An absolute treasure
review: Of course, we went to the Taj Mahal. But we also listened to a friend who lives in Delhi and advised us not to miss the tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah. It was the best moment of a fabulous day. I can only repeat what the previous reviewer said. The delicate marble decoration is positively stunning, you can spend hours admiring the walls, inside and outside the elegant building, and you can do so leisurely: there were hardly 20 other people when we visited, during late afternoon, with the sun slowly setting over the Yamuna. The place exudes serenity and spirituality, and allows you to meditate on love in a way you cannot really do amid the crowds pushing and shoving at the Taj Mahal. After all, the Itimad-ud-Daulah is also a monument to love, in this case the love of a daughter for her parents.

title: Beautiful and peaceful building
review: Beautiful and peaceful building.  Recommend seeing this and the other Agra heritage sites before you see the Taj to get a better insight into the architectural style and detail.

title: More detail in the stone work than even the Taj Mahal
review: While significantly smaller than the Taj, we found that in many ways it was more beautiful.  The color and detail of the stone work was so varied and artistic.  The grounds were a delight to walk around.  The lattice-work in the stone is also especially nice.  Give yourself at least an hour to enjoy this gem.

title: I loved the Baby Taj, quite and lovely
review: This miniature Taj Mahal was really quite after visiting the actual Taj. The structure was beautiful, and the marble work was very intricate. The inside was very cool temperature wise with little to look at, but still a great visit! Quick too!

title: Baby Taj
review: Known as the baby Taj, this tomb was the model for the Taj Mahal. It is a small, elegant jewel box of a building and the first all marble Mughal building. It is just across the Yamuna River from Agra Fort, with good views across the river.

title: * Don't leave this one out!!!*
review: I mean it. I hadn't realised how important this was, and could have easily skipped it!! Thank God I didn't. This tomb probably has the most beautiful interior I've ever seen. Far more exciting than the interior of the taj mahal (for me). It's not on the same scale as the taj mahal, not a monumental thing. It is just a stunning gem of a site. Exquisitely detailed design. Go!!!

title: Fore runner to the Taj
review: This was the first Mughal building to be built entirely of marble.  It also precedes the building of the Taj.The marble walls are decorated with inscriptions from the Quran. The tomb is surrounded by beautiful gardens. There were not many visitors when we were there, so it was easy to walk around and enjoy the beautiful inlay work.

title: Baby Taj
review: It is often called "The Baby Taj" as it one of the most elegant momuments in the area. When you are inside make sure you take photos of the ceiling using a flash, otherwise you won't be able to appreciate the wonderful colours and shapes.

title: beautiful building ...looks like a jewel box
review: An app called iTajPlus which runs on iPhone was my guide. It has an excellent audio tour which is free on the app. I downloaded it before leaving for Agra.

title: Another worthy monument to visit
review: The Architecture and serenity of the tomb are good and worth seeing when in Agra. Better to go at the early hours or late evening. And more so with a good tour guide.

title: Beautiful
review: This tomb was one of the many beautiful tombs and palaces we had the pleasure of visiting on our trip.  The architecture here is just amazing.  We thoroughly enjoyed taking it all in.

title: Worth the time
review: Would recommend to see anything in Agra before seeing Taj Mahal.

title: Truely the Jewel Box in Marble
review: This structure contains marevelous paintied walls and ceilings and are not as commong as the inlay and carvings of other places. The inlay of course gives it its nicname of the jewel box in marble. Very worth a visit.

title: mini taj mahal
review: beautiful calligraphy in white marble well preserved.and mainly no crowds here.its called mini taj mahal but the marble work is even better here.

title: Smaller version of the Taj but much more delicate
review: Less crowds and the workmanship much more refined than the Taj. If you have time, you should visit this too and compare the difference.

title: Didn't like it much
review: This is also called Mini Taj. But if you have already visited Taj, you won't like it much. It just looks as a real big model of the Taj.

title: A must see!
review: This is a good place to visit: the tomb is definitely less gigantic than the Taj, but it is very beautiful and quite relaxing, since not many people get there.

title: Baby Taj
review: It is still in good shape and really shows that it was the prelude to the TAJ.A  beautiful monument made by Nur Jahan.

title: Baby Taj - Beautiful detail
review: This is an exquisiste site with such lovely detail. So breathtaking and wonderful. A true marvel. This is often referred to as the Baby Taj Mahal, as its much smaller but with much more detail than the Taj. A must see.

title: beautiful
review: This tomb was built by a Mughal Emperor's (Mongolian) queen as memorial to her father. It's not as famous only because it is sharing the stage with Taj Mahal.

title: Skip Taj Mahal - see this jewel instead
review: We genuinely found this tomb to be one of the most beautiful monuments we visited -- and were far more impressed by it than the Taj Mahal (see my review for the Taj). Give this jewel a chance!

title: Second Taj
review: Itimad-ud-Daulah precedes the Taj by about 80 to 100 years. The first total marble mausoleum of mughal era, which was the inspiration for Taj . Built by NoorJahan for her farther this building has intricate colour stone inlay work on marble which can take the viewers breath away. The mausoleum is in very good condition and a must visit for anyone who is going to Agra to see Taj.

title: Quiet place
review: after we enter agra from express way this is the first monument we see in agra,  it is a building much smaller and different style. fact remains that it has its own charm and exquisite inlays, also snubbed from the tourist crowds and you can enjoy it in peace and quiet

title: Nicely Maintained Tomb
review: Well maintained from Outside, does not take more then 30 mins to go around , Needs a proper Parking facility!

title: Baby Taaj-
review: must see. its a nice tomb. Take pics from the central tomb. Listen the echo at the central tomb. . . . . . . . . . . . . .  . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

title: Loved Baby Taj
review: Yes that is what they call it over there. It lacks the grandeaur and the eternal love feeling attached to Tajmahal. In all other respect, probably Itimad-ud-Daulah is better. The carvings, the details are better and this one is older than the Taj. I heard that this monument was the inspiration for TajMahal's design. you can spend some quality time here as not too many people visit this place and you would not find mad crowd here as you would at the TajMahal. However, no guides or photographers here.

title: An often missed Attraction
review: Tomb of Noor Jahan's father. Though small in size when we compare it with Taj Mahal, it is unique in its own way. A precursor of Taj with respect to general layout. One of the best things about this site is , that because for some reason it has less visitors it has been very well preserved, the inlay work and the carvings are just fantastic. One can study at leisure.

title: Well preserved
review: Part of India's fascinating history and we really enjoyed our trip to agra. Spend 2 days in agra to see it all.

title: Beautiful
review: After the Taj and the Fort we relaxed at this beautiful gem, just on the other side of the Yamunna. Worth a visit.

title: visit if u have spare time
review: good place with huge tombs and green grass overall an avearage place to visit if u have spare time in your itinerary

title: Breathtaking
review: Just as breathtaking as the Taj Mahal but without the crowds! Our guide Akram Ali who we booked through Viator, made our day in Agra so special with his expertise and in depth knowledge of Indian history.  He explained things so simply and his English is impeccable.  We would have missed so much had Akram not been with us.  We loved India and are planning to visit again.  When we do we will definitely book Akram again.  His services are invaluable to appreciate the beautiful sights you are seeing.  The Taj Mahal is without doubt amazing but don't leave Agra without seeing this gem also!

title: Quiet place with lovely inlay work.
review: After being underwhelmed by the Taj, I really enjoyed my excursion here. There were only a handful of other people there so you have time for photos and to focus on the details. Well worth the trip across the river.

title: Better than the Taj
review: Much better than the Taj Mahal and for free. Just get a rickshaw driver to take you there before sunrise, you'll be amazed by the colors and the beauty of this monument... there's no tourists around and you might be the only one enjoying this beauty.

title: Don't miss it
review: Amazing place.. Quiet, very few visitors.. You can spend a good amount of time as there is no rush of tourists.. The carvings and stone work on marble is better than that at the Taj..

title: nice
review: this a small tomb also known as baby taj , it is a small tomb, they don't give you audio guides, so i recommend read your travel book before going there

title: Mini taj
review: It looks like a smaller version of the taj mahal except for the dome.it was built for Mumtaz Mahal's grandfather

title: A great place
review: It's a very nice place - picturesque and quiet. Go there right before sunset to enjoy the view of the "baby Taj Mahal". You'll like it there!

title: A real surprise
review: Much smaller than the Taj, it predates it.  It has its own grace and loveliness.  The two things that surprised me most were how different it was to the Taj despite not a large difference in time of building and the resemblance of much of the design work to things we had seen in Morocco.  Many of the patterns and techniques were identical.  Perhaps they came from Arabia, where a lot of the Moroccan tradesmen had travelled.

title: A hidden surprise
review: I was equally amazed to see this monument, as I was on seeing the Taj mahal. The work in this monument is much more intricate and beautiful than the Taj Mahal. Taj Mahal is much talked about and popular, but this one also deserves to be seen by everyone visiting Agra.

title: Serenely Beautiful!
review: Not too many tourists in the evening and it's beautiful tomb. The work on it is exquisite. The beauty of the place is matching the Taj only much smaller. If time permits, do visit the place!

title: Must see next to Taj Mahal
review: The call it the Baby Taj, which sort of gives you the impression its not worthwhile to go see. But its beautifull and with little tourists its a great to stroll around. Its much smaller so it wont cost you that much time.

title: Beautiful
review: While lacking the grandeur of the Taj, this little tomb is really spectacular. The art and inlay work is second to none. It's also a lot quieter than the Taj. I went about 8 am and was the only tourist there.

title: Beautiful and peaceful
review: The tomb was a little away from our hotel but well worth the visit. It is quiet and peaceful and not a mela like the Taj. You can actually soak up the beauty of the monument without being rushed. The tomb has a lot of intricate work and is stunning from close quarters. We didn't take a guide and instead just walked around admiring the tomb and the gardens and structures around it and clicking lots of pictures.

title: great monument
review: one of the monuments you should never miss when in agra. it is worth the visit.  see the carvings and the granduer of this monuments and the finer details paid attention to.

title: unique building
review: Hi, i am going to write something about Itimad ud daulah (baby taj) i like it very much . so many tourist come to see the Taj Mahal , in Agra and after that they leave ,  some of them go to see the Baby taj mahal , But many of them doesn't go to see it . While it is a first building in which people can see the gorgeous craftsmanship and it is the first example of inlay work india , which was built before than taj mahal . it  was built by noor jahan who was the mother of emperor shahanjan.

title: Gem of a find
review: Baby Taj or 'jewel box' it is often called.  The tomb of Mumtaz Mahal's grandfather is a stunning piece of architecture with both red sandstone and marble edifices.  Sadly decaying, the paintings inside are somewaht niaive but quite vivid and well worth seeing.

title: Awesome, amazing
review: This tomb, hardly known and rarely visited/mentioned, is one of the finest examples of the great architecture of the Mughal period. In some sense, it overtakes even the Taj in terms of quality of work.

title: Mini Taj
review: A lot quieter than the Taj Mahal and very colourful murals. Enjoyed this site as much as the Taj Mahal.

title: A Jewel!
review: not to be missed!! though reaching the site can be a pain sometimes ( as we experienced it) it was well worth a visit, do recommend it to all

title: Baby Taj... Beautiful .. Just as majestic as Taj Mahal
review: Dont miss this!!! As beautiful as the full sized Taj Mahal. However I found this site much more peaceful and quiet. I enjoyed just sitting back for an hour and wandering the grounds leiserely.. Very beautiful walls and easier to view than at the Full sized Taj.  Lots of animals here. We got to see monkeys wandering around the grounds as well as some interesting birds.

title: Baby Taj is cute
review: Smaller than Taj Mahal, and not crowded (an advantage, it looks that tourists don't flock here). You can enjoy the wonders of semiprecious stones embedding on marble, in a precious building. The second must in Agra after the Tah Mahal.

title: Deserves the name Baby Taj
review: Breathtaking mausoleum, beautiful marble carving outside and great wall paintings inside. No need to get a guide.

title: Inspiration for Taj Mahal
review: Commissioned by Nur Jahan, wife of Jehangir for her father, Ghiyas Ali Beg or Itmad-ud-Daulah, this is the first Mughal Building made of white marble. Many people believe that this is also the inspiration for the magnificent Taj Mahal and one can easily notice the uncanny similarity between the two.

title: Very well preserved
review: They call it the Baby Taj.  This is a beautiful tomb also with really wonderful detail of inlaid precious stones and is really a beautiful place.  Don't be put off by the guy watching the shoes as he will ask for 100INR.  Thats up to you but its not mandatory.  Wear socks as the ground can be very hot to walk on with the sun beating down.

title: Cute Architecture
review: Nor Jahan's memorial for her parents. This is a very under hyped place, one hardly sees any tourists around but really a must visit.

title: Often Missed
review: It was really good to visit this with a knowledgeable Guide; excellent to see that there are funds to do some upgrade work; got some fantastic photos.

title: Better than the Taj Mahal!
review: I was so impressed with Itimad-ud-Daulah!  Not many tourists were there and most of the people that were there were all locals.  There were couples picnicking on the green outside this beautiful structure and boys swimming in the river.  It was very relaxed.  I highly recommend a visit after seeing the Taj Mahal.  This smaller structure is better preserved and has beautiful, intricate designs not seen at the bigger version of itself, the Taj Mahal.

title: Hidden Treasure
review: Nicknamed "the Jewel Box" this is a must-see if you are visiting Agra.  It predates the Taj Mahal, but is built in a similar style.  Most people visit the Taj and the Agra Fort, but never get to Itimad-ud-Daulah, which is really a shame because it is so beautiful AND without the crowds of other attractions.  The buidling is absolutely stunning; it is so intricately carved that it looks like lace against the blue sky.  Well worth the visit!  If you are daring, have an auto rickshaw take you there and enjoy the wild ride over the bridge across the river.

title: The Artwork alone is Amazing
review: Ok so we went here after seeing the Taj and as you enter you think oh yeah it hasn't the white majestic outside appearance of the Taj it is smaller but very similar.  Then you learn this was built before the Taj so already you thinking this is pretty cool.  It is quiet no crowds and you feel like your in heaven because as you enter inside you have found the real treasure as the art work on the walls and ceiling are simply breathtaking and you can gaze for ages.  Do yourself a favour and go see this as it is delightfully bliss

title: its poor
review: no guide available to explain , you dont understand what is where and most important is not clean at all

title: A baby Taj just as interesting
review: A smaller version of the Taj over looking the river nearer town. very quiet whilst we were there so we were able to stroll around quite leisurely and enjoy the peace and quiet. Do not miss it well worth the effort.

title: The Mini Taj
review: Beautiful structure which has even more details on its marble walls than the Taj! Very well maintained, one can get great views of the Sunset by the banks of the Yamuna where this tomb is located.

title: Fab and very quiet
review: A really beautiful place- and has some of the features of the Taj which seems to have earned it the name locally of 'the baby Taj'-with out the hords of visitors that you get at the real Taj-well worth a visit if you have time

title: baby Taj
review: Located on the left bank of the Yamuna river, the mausoleum is set in a large cruciform garden criss-crossed by water courses and walkways.The mausoleum was commissioned by Nūr Jahān, the wife of Jahangir, for her father Mirzā Ghiyās Beg, originally a Persian Amir in exile .[1] who had been given the title of I'timād-ud-Daulah (pillar of the state). Mirzā Ghiyās Beg was also the grandfather of Mumtāz Mahāl (originally named Arjūmand Bāno, daughter of Asaf Khān), the wife of the emperor Shāh Jahān, responsible for the building of the Tāj Mahal.

title: it is very good...see it if you are in agra
review: It is a beautiful building...you must see it if you are in Agra...It is not crowded either

title: The Lord Treasurer's Tomb
review: The landscaped grounds of the Tomb are beautiful. We visited the tomb in the afternoon,

title: Worth the visit
review: Slightly out of the way, unless you arrive into Agra by road on the new highway from Delhi, however well worth the visit. As with many of the Mughal sites it is intricately constructed and well preserved. Referred to as the Baby Taj it's easy to see why with its shining white marbled appearance set on bank of the Yamuna River. Not as heavily populated as the Taj, take the time to pay a visit as it won't disappoint.

title: Baby Taj
review: As the precursor to the Taj Mahal - it is well worth a visit.   Similar in many respects it provides a perspective on the Taj Mahal which is well worth seeing.

title: a nice intro before the real thing
review: It is certainly worthwhile to get to the Baby Taj. Be sure to do it before going to the real thing. Real neat mozaic and marble, and nice and quiet.

title: Visit when you are in Agra anyway
review: This is the small brother of the Taj Mahal, and probably gave some inspiration to the design of Taj Mahal. It is worthwhile visiting, when you are in Agra anyway. It is pretty quiet, not many tourists.

title: On the way to Taj
review: Called the baby taj, located on the west bank of river yamuna. Try flashing a camera on the ceiling of the main room and see the picture you get. amazing

title: Baby Taj
review: Well worth a visit.  Smaller than the Taj Mahal, but impressive none the less. Very peaceful and far less busy / commercial than the Taj Mahal. If you take a rickshaw there you can also tag on a visit to the north bank of the river where there some great views of the Taj Mahal across the river :)

title: real beauty
review: Amazing architecture.  Unbelievable craft. The main building looks so light as if it is suspended in the air.  Not so many visitors, so there is a chance to see more and spend some time just enjoying the beauty of the Tomb and surroundings.  Quietness and serenity of the monument are  impressively different to a very busy town life in Agra that one can observe on other side of the river.

title: Mini-Taj
review: A lovely mini-Taj style building with lovely art work.

title: As impressive as the Taj Mahal
review: Try to add this in - its impressive, beautiful, uncrowded and quick! Often known as the Baby Taj, in any other city people would be queuing up to see this but its overshadowed by the Taj Mahal.

title: more of the same
review: not really impressed, would not reccommend to spend valuable time to visit this monument

title: Worth going.
review: Beautiful mausoleum, nice garden, peacefull, silent. I enjoyed a lot.

title: Make sure you see it!
review: Said to be the least visited of the 3 big sites in Agra, this should be a must see.  For one thing, it is much smaller and more intimate than the Taj Mahal.  Sometimes called the baby Taj, it was an inspiration for the Taj Mahal.

title: The Mini Taj Mahal
review: This is the lesser known attraction in Agra, and most tour operators may not take you here. But trust me, this is one tomb you must visit. Apparently, this was the precursor to the Taj - kind of the original marble building that triggered a series of other Mughal marble constructions with Taj being the pinnacle.

title: Not to miss, this precurser to the Taj
review: Itmad-ud daulah, one of the most beautiful of Mughal tombs, stands across the river Yamuna from the Taj Mahal, nearly one and a half kilometers up-stream. Belonging to the age of Jahangir, it contains cenotaphs of Mirza Ghiyas and Asmat Begum, parents of the powerful Mughal Empress Nurjahan queen of Jahangir, an exceptional beauty and an astute administrator.  The pure white and elaborately carved tomb of Itmad-ud-Daulah conforms to the Islamic style of architecture. The use of arched entrances, octagonal shaped towers or minarets, use of exquisitely carved floral patterns, intricate marble-screen work and inlay work are all representative of the Islamic style. The absence of a dome and the presence of a closed kiosk on top of this building and the use of chhatris (small domed canopies, supported by pillars) atop the four towers (minarets) instead of proper domes are reflective of local influence.

title: AKA "Baby Taj"
review: We had two nights in Agra and after seeing the Taj Mahal in the morning (early to avoid the heat and crowds) we went out to the Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah (known to the rickshaw drivers as Baby Taj) in the afternoon. Impressive architecture - and we drove through the real Agra (the much less touristy bit) to get there which was equally fascinating.

title: Well worth visiting and doesn't have the crowds
review: This impressive building right on the riverbank has some beautiful carving and whilst it doesn't have the grandeur of the Taj, it is much more intimate and I think gives a greater feel of history. It's known as the Baby Taj for obvious reasons. It's well worth the longish trip in an autorickshaw.

title: nice but in bad condition
review: I very interesting place but in quite poor condition.

title: Great contrasts for photos
review: They call this a little gem and it is. We were there in the heat of the day so there weren't many other visitors and it was quiet in the sun. The site itself is magnificent, especially the gold and paintings on the ceilings but especially fabulous was the excellent contrasting views of the city and bridge---from preserved beauty and stateliness to the ramshackle, crowded buildings of Agra itself w people drying sheets on the sand of the river and water buffalos wallowing in the mud.

title: Loved this place
review: We had this place to ourselves, the building is exquisite, don't miss it.

title: pre-dates the Taj!
review: 1st example of indo-islam architecture!  we went late int eh day and fond hardly any crowds!  Wow!

title: Baby Taj
review: Much preferred to Taj Mahal - intricate carvings are beautiful, and very very quiet - worth the jaunt!

title: Baby Taj
review: Cute! If one is allowed to use the adjective for a tomb. Excellent afternoon experience away from the hustle and bustle around the Taj.

title: ok
review: If you like architecture , do not miss this building !!

title: Beautiful setting
review: Another Tomb but different and still spectacular, lovely grounds and no other visitors.

title: Exquisite tomb
review: Sometimes called the Baby Taj.  Stunning design and no-one seems to visit, we had the place to ourselves and spent quite a long time wandering around the building and gardens, well worth going.

title: Not so good
review: I don't know what went wrong but I didn't like this place much.

title: Baby Taj
review: People say it as Baby Taj. But not similar to real Taj Mahal in any angle. Place to visit once if you are in agra.

title: one of my Highlights in India
review: Taj Mahal done

title: Should be seen if only to put it into perspective
review: The Baby Taj.

title: Beautiful, uncrowded - definitely worth a visit
review: A definite highlight. Beautiful stonework much more to see on the inside than the Taj and absolute masterpiece. We got there late afternoon and there were maybe 10 other people there. Lovely grounds for relaxing in, just watch the monkeys! A shame they charge to use the bathroom. Unnecessary given you've paid to get in. Oh and avoid the beggar girl who throws stones at you if you don't give her money. Ignoring those irritations the place is stunning and a 'must visit'.

title: Architectural Marvel
review: The building makes justice to the person buried inside... Emperor Akbar... huge place for one man... but then he was true emperor.. respected all three religons HINDU, CHRISTIAN and ISLAM... one can see all three styles adopted in building by architect.... Grave of AUrangzebs daughter ZEBUNNISA begum is also inside... and so are some architectural marvels on acoustics.... speak in corner to one pillar and sound travels diagonally across and you can hear it clearly at the other pillars... can todays architects build something similar...?

title: Baby taj
review: Often described as 'jewel box', sometimes called the 'Baby Taj', the tomb of I'timād-ud-Daulah is often regarded as a draft of the Tāj Mahal. One of the finest places to visit during your trip to Agra

title: The Baby Taj
review: It's indeed a smaller version of the Taj Mahal only 10 min away from Taj Ganj. The Tomb is beautiful from the outside and ok in the inside.

title: Baby Taj
review: Very nice and peachful, lots of detailed marble work.

title: Real Indian art
review: If you like architect operas, do not miss this building !!

title: Very worth seeing
review: Enjoy other sites as well as the Taj Mahal. Take a day just to see the Tomb's and gardens.

title: Baby taj, utterly lovely!
review: Arguably nicer than the taj they say.

title: Oh for a helicopter
review: The amazing tower which when viewed from directly overhead resembles a lotus flower - but you need a helicopter to see it!

title: Peaceful spot
review: Lovely stonework, mosaics, some of it damaged. Also known as the baby Taj.  Interesting views over the river.

title: Exquisite
review: Smaller than the Taj Mahal the marble inlay is nonetheless quite stunning. It is set in a smaller park on the river but has four gates and a mogul garden. This tomb also features many paintings.

title: Nice stone work.
review: This site offers the opportunity to examine the artistry of the stone carvers up close and without the press of large crowds.  Getting there with all the traffic at mid-day was quite problematic, but it is worth the effort.

title: beautiful
review: definately to be on the visit itinery. oasis of calm with stunning  architecture and setting.

title: Baby Taj
review: Both my husband and I enjoy this area more than visiting the Tal Mahal.  Exquisite detail and no huge crowds.

title: Wonderfully build ! Check it out
review: I loved everything except too many people. I advice spend some more time hear and get understanding about history of this place

title: Fascinating
review: I love the timeless feel - so much history . Wonderful designs

title: exceptionally delicate details
review: We visited the Itimad-ud-daulah first and it blew my mind.  The exquisite intricate marble carvings and the perfectly painted and decorated walls and ceiling left me speechless - The Taj Mahal we visited next and, although amazing, paled into insignificence after the exquisite perfection of Itimad-du-daulah

title: a lovely little gem
review: this is known as the Baby Taj and is a beautiful tranquil site. I really enjoyed my time here and wish we could have stayed a bit longer to sit and enjoy the cosiness of the site compared to other large sites

title: "Mini Taj"
review: Lower entrance fee than the Taj Mahal, and a little more realistic structure for what is no more than a memorial for a dead person.

title: The Baby Taj
review: Many thanks to our driver who after our guide dropped us back to the hotel brought us to this monument , dont miss it!!

title: Small monument
review: liked the ambience , less crowd

title: Beautiful Intricate Detail Seen Here!
review: Smaller monument, small crowd, but it's a beautiful building nonetheless. The walls here are more detailed than at the Taj Mahal.

title: baby taj!
review: a smaller scale of taj mahal. certainly not as impressive as the taj itself, but the lack of people, and well maintained place makes it a very relaxing place to spend afternoon. go if you have time though, for i find myself enjoying sitting by the side and read a book with a magnificent building in front of me, instead of going crazy over the building itself. once you see the real taj, nothing can rival it.

title: Beautiful
review: It is beautiful and because of no undesirable elements and least crowd,we enjoyed more.

title: Quiet spot in Agra
review: Lovely tomb along the Yamuna river, on the opposite side from the Taj. The gardens are peaceful and often full of kids and families enjoying the open green space.  Much smaller and less crowded than the Taj.  Highly recommend a visit if you have time while in Agra.

title: Loved the "Baby Taj"
review: As it is fondly and popularly called.. the site was built by Noor Jehan before Taj was built.

title: Beautiful Landscapes
review: During the sunset, the landscape of Baby Taj and the river create a very beautiful portrait. Photographers would love it!

title: lovely site
review: worth the detour. Beautiful mosaics.  Be sure to go inside.

title: Lovely and quiet
review: This small mausoleum offers what the Taj Mahal cannot - the opportunity to enjoy Mughul marble workmanship without crowds and noise.

title: Lovely peaceful place
review: Very peaceful location next to river, hardly any tourists compared with the Taj Mahal. Interesting to see the transition in architecture between Itimad-ud-Daulah, Humayun's tomb in Delhi, Akbar's tomb at Sikandra and Taj Mahal

title: Beautiful, small but impressive.
review: It's a small place and of course not as impressive as the Taj, but it is beautiful, I think probably more detailed work (lots of engravings) than the Taj (Not sure about this though)

title: A lovely piece of art.
review: Not so crowded; very well maintained and so different form taj mahal. Carvings and pietradura are breath taking.

title: Baby Taj was nice
review: A smaller version of Taj Mahal. Discount on the entry if you visit on the same day as Taj Mahal.

title: Training before a Taj visit
review: This monument offers a unique possibility to learn about Mughal architecture without the rush and the crowds of Taj Mahal. This is a tomb of a noble family whose head used to be the prime minister of the famous Shah Jahan.

title: The inspiration for the Taj Mahal.  Smaller and more delicate.
review: If you are a fan of historic fiction, I suggest that you read "The Twentieth Wife" to learn about the life of Nur Jahan who built this monument / tomb for her family.  She was the favorite wife of Jehangir (father of Shah Jahan, who built th Taj) and the aunt of Mumtaz, for whom the Taj was built.

title: clean and really attractive....
review: This placee is not a detailed architechtural largre building...but very attractive and consist of wonderful work of white marble...well maintained less crowded...you can spend some time peacefully ...with good photographic opportunities..

title: Precursor to the Taj
review: Built a generation before the Taj, this little jewel box is a short 20 minute hop on the Agra tourist trail. Neat views of the Jamuna river from the gardens.

title: The baby Taj
review: We saw this before going to the Taj Mahal which is the best order to do it. It is a lovely location on the bank of the Yamuna river and was not crowded. The mausoleum is very beautiful. I wish there were souvenir brochures in English explaining the history as the large plaque was hard to read.

title: Missable
review: Missable. Maybe if you've seen nothing else in India, this would be nice, but Humayun's Tomb in Delhi is much more fitting of the title "Baby Taj" than this underwhelming tomb.

title: Not the Taj but well worth seeing
review: Quieter than the Taj, with nice views of the river, with water buffalo, about a 20 minute (and hair raising!) ride in an auto rickshaw.

title: Baby Taj
review: It was not crowded and by the time I got there the fog was gone so the view was nice. It is worth seeing. Keep your shoe covers from the Taj or you have to rent them or pay the guy if you take your shoes off. Everyone has their hand out.

title: beautiful
review: Although the architecture echos the Taj Majal, the art work is unique and beautiful.  It's a must see in Agra.

title: очень красиво
review: Потрясающая архитектура, белый мрамор и полудрагоценные камни

title: Holds its own with the Taj Mahal
review: Much smaller and less crowded but with even more intricate design detail.  The colours in the late afternoon were stunning and its location by the river is beautiful.  Worth fitting in if you can.

title: must see
review: we did this on our tour on agra and we loved the history of the building and the story that goes with it if you have time make sure you see this

title: Baby Taj
review: Beautiful to see baby Taj & much easier to visit than the more famous Taj

title: Keep your Ticket!
review: Baby Taj is, in my opinion, one of the sites involved in the re-issuing of tickets scam.  The man who should rip your ticket kept ours and told us to get it on the way out.  When we asked for them, he claimed he had 'put them in the box', a practice not done elsewhere in India.  When we pressed, he ripped one ticket on the spot and gave us the stub.  Keep your ticket stubs, and don't let them rip off tourists!! In all other aspects the site is beautiful.

title: Jewel Box in Marble
review: Left it late in the day to visit this, and ended up being the only two peolpe at the tomb.  The sun was setting, and we obtained some brilliant photo's - great for the camera enthusiast. Lovely gardens from the exquiste tomb, situated off the east bank of the Yamuna river.  Tidy and clean, no evidence of any litter, although they could of swept up at the end of the day.   The mosaic patterns are amazing.

title: well worth a visit
review: Besides the taj and agra fort this site is well worth a visit when you're in Agra. It's not so big so it won't necessary take a lot of time. Unless of course you want to hang out here a bit longer as it is quite a calm place. Basically it consists of one big square garden with in the middle the tomb ('baby taj..') and some -almost identical- buildings at the beginning of each path (comming in from every side of the garden) leading to the tomb. It's nice and quite and there are not so much visitors.

title: Worth a Visit
review: Take the trouble to see this. Not as impressive as the Taj mahal perhaps but very beautiful.

title: Passed the time
review: OK, nothing special. Nothing memorable.

title: A Must to Visit
review: Fascinating, great inlay work using some amazing stone.  The whole sight is in a reasonable condition.  Some areas very good  Take your shoe covers from the Taj.

title: "Baby Taj" is well worth the visit
review: This is a marvellous place that is much less crowded than the Taj Mahal and the Red Fort.  There is a restfulness that is hard to find in the madness of India.

title: Visit the baby Taj after Taj Mahal.
review: A smaller version of the Taj Mahal with very different architecture and fewer tourists in your photos.  Nice grounds.  Photos allowed inside, unlike the Taj Mahal.

title: A tomb to be "proud" of.....
review: Nur Jahan certainly did her father proud when she had this elegant jewel of a tomb built for him.  There are beautiful niches, with painted floral designs. There are marble screens carved from a single slab of marble with complex designs.  You may find you are struggling to see the fine detail of the corners and ceiling of the tomb chamber - I strongly recommend you take a torch - if you haven't one, take a picture and you will see in your photograph the beauty and exquisite design and workmanship of this tomb.      So far its uncrowded and 2 miles upstream from the Taj Mahal.

title: very important site and it is in poor condition but well maintained.
review: it was in poor status and needs lot of repair. It is a burial place for the family of Mumtaz Mahal and her parents.

title: Do not miss the 'Baby Taj'
review: Much more impressive than expected.  Really peaceful park and well preserved, relatively small but elegant monument, which was truly impressive.  Do not miss this if in Agra, the guidebook description ‘jewel box in marble’ is correct.

title: Baby Taj
review: The best part about this is the fact that very few people care to visit it and so one can take his time to look at the intricate marble carvings including colored ones at one's leisure. It is not as spectacular or enormous as the Taj but had it been in a place other than Agra people would have thronged to see it even more. It is the biggest star in the sky where the Sun is the Taj!

title: A bit dull and ill cared for
review: To say it's called the 'Baby Taj' you would think it wouild be treated with a little more importance.  It's tired and dirty, although there was restoration work in hand, so maybe it will get better

title: Great  baby Taj
review: Before going to the big Taj, come and see this little beauty. The carvings are even more minuciously done than in the famous version!

title: Really loved this
review: We went to this tomb in the afternoon and it was really peaceful. It was a good preview for our visit to the Taj the next day. The colours in the stonework are just exquisite.

title: Underrated site
review: Wonderful prototype of the Taj,  Only a few touts and beggars outside.  The aschictechture is more detailed than the Taj -- inlay that is.

title: Baby Taj
review: If you visit the Taj Mahal - you will want to also see the Baby Taj

title: A gem across the river from the Taj Mahal
review: This tomb is very interesting despite the lack of great maintenance. The Taj Mahal suffers from the same issue but none the less this is a must see as well. The inlay work is marvelous and the ability to take pictures inside the tomb (unlike the Taj Mahal) allows you to see some of the other intricate work that goes into such monuments. There are fewer visitors so you get a more intimate sense of the tomb and all its chambers. Some of the lattice work is some of the finest in India and a must see as it is just across the river from its more famous sister.

title: very tranquil
review: a very peaceful little less-known site across the river from the main town

title: Dont miss it!
review: For some ridiculous reason it is known as the "Bay Taj".  It is nothing like  it, and in many ways a more enjoyable place.  Fewer people, lovely setting, a beautiful quiet symetry about the whole setting of the tomb and the gardens.  The colours of the stonework inlay are inferior to  the Taj,  but there are some witty features to e enjoyed in a peaceful setting: something the Taj will never have to offer.

title: If the Taj Mahal weren't here this would be the best.
review: A wonderful tomb.  Beautiful construction n the classical manner.  Overshadowed by the Taj but well worth a stop to learn and see it.

title: nice
review: The nickname of that temple is Baby Taj because it’s a little bit alike the big Taj. You have to pay Rs. 110 entrance fee, there is no extra charge for the camera. We really can recommend visiting the Baby Taj if the sun is going down because the Baby Taj lightens up in a really different way and there is the opportunity to do some amazing shots. Behind the Baby Taj is a river, which gives the place a special feeling.  It’s not that much to see but it’s still worth visiting the Baby Taj.

title: A real gem of a building that takes less than an hour to tour.
review: Intricate, beautiful marble inlay and lattice work as well as painted panels and ceilings. A small attraction which will not take very long to view, but is worth it if you have spare time.

title: Beautifull Monument
review: The Itimad ud daulah is probably one of the most underated monuments in India. With its spectacular stonework and persian color hues it is a treat to see. Being in the shadow of the taj mahal this monument is not crowded which gives you ample time to study the sructure and if lucky talk to the curator. This is a true blend of Mughal and persian architecture.

title: Such a cute little Taj
review: After the big is beautiful show-offyness of the Taj Mahal, the Itimad-Ud-Daulah, is much less overwhelming, much less popular, but oh so much more pretty.

title: A great monument
review: Turning upstream after crossing the river Yamuna,a rare experience awaits the visitor at the tomb of the Empress Nurjahan`s father ,Mirza ghiyas begh, (Itimad-ud-daula),Reliance of the state, became the prime minister of Mughal empire in 1611. such range and variety as the designers presented in this small gem are altogether unique. Persian politesse, art styles and architectural conventions enjoyed unrivalled favour, prevailing taste was expressed to perfection in the tomb built by the empress for her father after his death in 1621. It was completed in 1628, the year after Jahangir`s death.

title: Skip it if you are short on time!
review: We were here after visiting Agra Fort.  Actually I was quite disappointed once I was at the entrance.  It didn't really worth the time if you are here for a short trip.  Entrance fees is Rs 110 per person and kids are free.  The nick name - 'Baby Taj' really fit the bill but minus the 'historical' feel.  No wonder there wasn't many people.  This place is on the other side of the Yamuna river.

title: Superlative craftsmanship & beauty, worth seeing even in a hurry!
review: My partner and I only had 24 hours in Agra. We had 4 must see sights: Taj Mahal, Agra Fort, Fatehpur Sikri and Itmad-ud-Daulah (which means 'Pillar of the State, the title given to the person whom this tomb was built for, Mirza Ghiyas Beg). Day 1 we arrived at about noon, giving us the afternoon for the Agra Fort. Day 2 meant getting up very early for the Taj, then the drive to Fatehpur Sikri and then lastly this 'Baby Taj'. With bad traffic on Agra's streets we only just made it 40 mins before closing time, but it really was worth it. Much has been said about how the proportions of this monument are not as perfect as the Taj itself, but to my mind, its relative quietness, intimate size and phenomenal inlay decoration (which is far superior to the Taj) make it a magical place to visit. Perhaps after praising how quiet and sedate it was, it is silly for me to recommend other travellers to make a beeline for it, but I was never one to keep my knowledge and good travel experiences to myself.

title: Not to be missed
review: A lovely little (by comparison) gem, easily visited in combination with Metab Bagh, beautifully situated along the river.

title: Beautiful Place to Visit
review: 15-20 minute autorickshaw drive from Agra Fort. You don't need to spend a lot of time here but I think it's worth seeing while in Agra. If you have more time to spend it's a nice place to sit and relax for a while.

title: Don't miss "Baby Taj" if you have the time.
review: "Baby Taj" as it's called is nowhere near as impressive as the Taj Mahal itself, but the incredible beauty of its creation is something you simply should see.  Take a guide with you for the best experience, so he can share with you the history and architecture, and explain to you the amazing feat this building actually is.  It is so beautifully decorated, even more so than the Taj Mahal itself, both inside and out, using gemstones on the white marble.

title: AWESOME
review: Not far from the Taj Mahal and just across the river from the Red Fort, this baby Taj is the most serene and beautiful building I have been to.  Yes the Taj Mahal is impressive, but in my mind this is much better.  If you miss out on this building, you hvn't seen India.

title: Unexpected surprise
review: We went here first  before visiting the Taj Mahal because it is referred to as the “Baby Taj”. We knew it didn’t look like the Taj but is a marble mausoleum that inspired the building of the Taj Mahal. It is a hidden gem in that it stands alone for its beauty and architecture. The carvings in the marble are incredible and a wonder to look at and ponder.

title: Don't skip it
review: The tomb is usually very quiet, and offers an unparalleled chance to examine truly gorgeous inlay work in the peace and reflective solitude that the crowds at Taj or Agra Fort don't let you have. When we went at midday on a Saturday, there were only a few dozen people in the whole complex, and it was much more serene (and clean!) than most places in Agra. The building is small, but exquisite, and offers a chance to see Iranian influences on Mughal aesthetic. It's a unique fusion of styles and motifs, and so, so worth it.

title: Agra is Not Just About Taj Mahal
review: Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah or also known as Baby Taj was so beautiful! The entry fee for foreigner is Rs 310. Also not so many people know this place so it is not crowded, and you can take as many pictures as you can. Also made of white marble, Baby Taj was said to be the inspiration of Taj Mahal. Baby Taj is the tomb made for Mumtaz Mahal's grandparents.

title: so beautiful monument
review: This is an iconic building. The first muslim monument, built completely with marble and immense use of inlay work. Karan from Sachan Walking Tours helped us to understand the gradual development of Islamic buildings in India. Another lovely tour of Baby Taj.

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: Baby Taj lacks nothing compared to the “big” Taj.
review: This building is truly a work of genius.  The inlay work and symmetry make this one of the most beautiful buildings in all of India.  Missed by many visitors to Agra, I would highly recommend making time to see it.

title: Great place of history...
review: This is a famous tourist size near the Taj mahal.. Place is a well built tomb but recommended to be travelled in winters as it is very hot in summers in agra..... Overall a great site to visit

title: About mini taj
review: it is nicely build at the bank of Yamuna river also called mini taj which is build by marbel. very beautiful.

title: Unexpected surprise
review: We went here first  before visiting the Taj Mahal because it is referred to as the “Baby Taj”. We knew it didn’t look like the Taj but is a marble mausoleum that inspired the building of the Taj Mahal. It is a hidden gem in that it stands alone for its beauty and architecture. The carvings in the marble are incredible and a wonder to look at and ponder.

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: Not to be missed
review: A lovely little (by comparison) gem, easily visited in combination with Metab Bagh, beautifully situated along the river.

title: AWESOME
review: Not far from the Taj Mahal and just across the river from the Red Fort, this baby Taj is the most serene and beautiful building I have been to.  Yes the Taj Mahal is impressive, but in my mind this is much better.  If you miss out on this building, you hvn't seen India.

title: About mini taj
review: it is nicely build at the bank of Yamuna river also called mini taj which is build by marbel. very beautiful.

title: Great place of history...
review: This is a famous tourist size near the Taj mahal.. Place is a well built tomb but recommended to be travelled in winters as it is very hot in summers in agra..... Overall a great site to visit

title: AWESOME
review: Not far from the Taj Mahal and just across the river from the Red Fort, this baby Taj is the most serene and beautiful building I have been to.  Yes the Taj Mahal is impressive, but in my mind this is much better.  If you miss out on this building, you hvn't seen India.

title: Baby Taj lacks nothing compared to the “big” Taj.
review: This building is truly a work of genius.  The inlay work and symmetry make this one of the most beautiful buildings in all of India.  Missed by many visitors to Agra, I would highly recommend making time to see it.

title: Agra is Not Just About Taj Mahal
review: Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah or also known as Baby Taj was so beautiful! The entry fee for foreigner is Rs 310. Also not so many people know this place so it is not crowded, and you can take as many pictures as you can. Also made of white marble, Baby Taj was said to be the inspiration of Taj Mahal. Baby Taj is the tomb made for Mumtaz Mahal's grandparents.

title: so beautiful monument
review: This is an iconic building. The first muslim monument, built completely with marble and immense use of inlay work. Karan from Sachan Walking Tours helped us to understand the gradual development of Islamic buildings in India. Another lovely tour of Baby Taj.

title: Not to be missed
review: A lovely little (by comparison) gem, easily visited in combination with Metab Bagh, beautifully situated along the river.

title: Don't skip it
review: The tomb is usually very quiet, and offers an unparalleled chance to examine truly gorgeous inlay work in the peace and reflective solitude that the crowds at Taj or Agra Fort don't let you have. When we went at midday on a Saturday, there were only a few dozen people in the whole complex, and it was much more serene (and clean!) than most places in Agra. The building is small, but exquisite, and offers a chance to see Iranian influences on Mughal aesthetic. It's a unique fusion of styles and motifs, and so, so worth it.

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: Baby Taj lacks nothing compared to the “big” Taj.
review: This building is truly a work of genius.  The inlay work and symmetry make this one of the most beautiful buildings in all of India.  Missed by many visitors to Agra, I would highly recommend making time to see it.

title: Unexpected surprise
review: We went here first  before visiting the Taj Mahal because it is referred to as the “Baby Taj”. We knew it didn’t look like the Taj but is a marble mausoleum that inspired the building of the Taj Mahal. It is a hidden gem in that it stands alone for its beauty and architecture. The carvings in the marble are incredible and a wonder to look at and ponder.

When we went at midday on a Saturday, there were only a few dozen people in the whole complex, and it was much more serene (and clean!) than most places in Agra. The building is small, but exquisite, and offers a chance to see Iranian influences on Mughal aesthetic. It's a unique fusion of styles and motifs, and so, so worth it.

title: Baby Taj lacks nothing compared to the “big” Taj.
review: This building is truly a work of genius.  The inlay work and symmetry make this one of the most beautiful buildings in all of India.  Missed by many visitors to Agra, I would highly recommend making time to see it.

title: Agra is Not Just About Taj Mahal
review: Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah or also known as Baby Taj was so beautiful! The entry fee for foreigner is Rs 310. Also not so many people know this place so it is not crowded, and you can take as many pictures as you can. Also made of white marble, Baby Taj was said to be the inspiration of Taj Mahal. Baby Taj is the tomb made for Mumtaz Mahal's grandparents.

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: Great place of history...
review: This is a famous tourist size near the Taj mahal.. Place is a well built tomb but recommended to be travelled in winters as it is very hot in summers in agra..... Overall a great site to visit

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: About mini taj
review: it is nicely build at the bank of Yamuna river also called mini taj which is build by marbel. very beautiful.

title: Not to be missed
review: A lovely little (by comparison) gem, easily visited in combination with Metab Bagh, beautifully situated along the river.

title: AWESOME
review: Not far from the Taj Mahal and just across the river from the Red Fort, this baby Taj is the most serene and beautiful building I have been to.  Yes the Taj Mahal is impressive, but in my mind this is much better.  If you miss out on this building, you hvn't seen India.

Baby Taj is the tomb made for Mumtaz Mahal's grandparents.

title: Baby Taj lacks nothing compared to the “big” Taj.
review: This building is truly a work of genius.  The inlay work and symmetry make this one of the most beautiful buildings in all of India.  Missed by many visitors to Agra, I would highly recommend making time to see it.

title: Great place of history...
review: This is a famous tourist size near the Taj mahal.. Place is a well built tomb but recommended to be travelled in winters as it is very hot in summers in agra..... Overall a great site to visit

title: Unexpected surprise
review: We went here first  before visiting the Taj Mahal because it is referred to as the “Baby Taj”. We knew it didn’t look like the Taj but is a marble mausoleum that inspired the building of the Taj Mahal. It is a hidden gem in that it stands alone for its beauty and architecture. The carvings in the marble are incredible and a wonder to look at and ponder.

title: AWESOME
review: Not far from the Taj Mahal and just across the river from the Red Fort, this baby Taj is the most serene and beautiful building I have been to.  Yes the Taj Mahal is impressive, but in my mind this is much better.  If you miss out on this building, you hvn't seen India.

title: Not to be missed
review: A lovely little (by comparison) gem, easily visited in combination with Metab Bagh, beautifully situated along the river.

title: Unexpectedly good
review: It is similar to Taj Mahal in many ways, but I still found it worth the visit and recommend visiting this monument.

title: so beautiful monument
review: This is an iconic building. The first muslim monument, built completely with marble and immense use of inlay work. Karan from Sachan Walking Tours helped us to understand the gradual development of Islamic buildings in India. Another lovely tour of Baby Taj.

title: Agra is Not Just About Taj Mahal
review: Tomb of Itimad-ud-Daulah or also known as Baby Taj was so beautiful! The entry fee for foreigner is Rs 310. Also not so many people know this place so it is not crowded, and you can take as many pictures as you can. Also made of white marble, Baby Taj was said to be the inspiration of Taj Mahal. Baby Taj is the tomb made for Mumtaz Mahal's grandparents.

title: Don't skip it
review: The tomb is usually very quiet, and offers an unparalleled chance to examine truly gorgeous inlay work in the peace and reflective solitude that the crowds at Taj or Agra Fort don't let you have. When we went at midday on a Saturday, there were only a few dozen people in the whole complex, and it was much more serene (and clean!) than most places in Agra. The building is small, but exquisite, and offers a chance to see Iranian influences on Mughal aesthetic. It's a unique fusion of styles and motifs, and so, so worth it.
